node.title: DSNP
node.plaintext:
Here you can find detailed documentation regarding the current state of the
Decentralized Social Network Protocol, previous iterations and proposals for
future extensions.
node.html: Here you can find detailed documentation regarding the current state of the Decentralized Social Network Protocol, previous iterations and proposals for future extensions.

node.title: Testnet
node.plaintext:
The DSNP is backed by a blockchain network that helps applications find
messages.  This is our testnet version of that blockchain.
node.html: The DSNP is backed by a blockchain network that helps applications find messages.  This is our testnet version of that blockchain.

node.title: SDK
node.plaintext:
The Software Development Kit offers the core features, communication
facilitations, build configurations, and common components for DSNP-enabled
applications.
node.html: The Software Development Kit offers the core features, communication facilitations, build configurations, and common components for DSNP-enabled applications.

node.title: Example Client
node.plaintext:
Using the DSNP SDK, the Example Client demonstrates how to quickly integrate
with the DSNP and manage all three elements.
node.html: Using the DSNP SDK, the Example Client demonstrates how to quickly integrate with the DSNP and manage all three elements.

node.title: What We Do
node.excerpt:
DSNP.org is an independent non-profit organization, focused on the Decentralized
Social Network Protocol (DSNP). The organization fits within the umbrella of 
Project Liberty [https://www.projectliberty.io/#/about] as the provider of one
core component (the social graph protocol) that connects the many different
technologies that make up a decentralized social network. Both DSNP.org and
Project Liberty have been launched out of Unfinished Labs
[https://www.unfinishedlabs.io/] as part of their ef
node.plaintext:
DSNP.org is an independent non-profit organization, focused on the Decentralized
Social Network Protocol (DSNP). The organization fits within the umbrella of 
Project Liberty [https://www.projectliberty.io/#/about] as the provider of one
core component (the social graph protocol) that connects the many different
technologies that make up a decentralized social network. Both DSNP.org and
Project Liberty have been launched out of Unfinished Labs
[https://www.unfinishedlabs.io/] as part of their efforts to build public
infrastructure for the web that puts citizens at the center of an innovative,
inclusive web economy.
node.html: DSNP.org is an independent non-profit organization, focused on the Decentralized Social Network Protocol (DSNP). The organization fits within the umbrella of Project Liberty as the provider of one core component (the social graph protocol) that connects the many different technologies that make up a decentralized social network. Both DSNP.org and Project Liberty have been launched out of Unfinished Labs as part of their efforts to build public infrastructure for the web that puts citizens at the center of an innovative, inclusive web economy.

node.title: Isn't Proof Of Work terrible for the environment?
node.excerpt:
The entire world agrees that blockchain technology needs to evolve beyond Proof
Of Work.  As soon as new solutions are available, we are committed to adopting
new blockchain infrastructure and leaving behind Proof Of Work.
node.plaintext:
The entire world agrees that blockchain technology needs to evolve beyond Proof
Of Work.  As soon as new solutions are available, we are committed to adopting
new blockchain infrastructure and leaving behind Proof Of Work.
node.html: The entire world agrees that blockchain technology needs to evolve beyond Proof Of Work.  As soon as new solutions are available, we are committed to adopting new blockchain infrastructure and leaving behind Proof Of Work.

node.title: Why Blockchain Technology?
node.excerpt:
Blockchain technology provides a means for implementing a truly decentralized
social network where no single authority can control any one user's data and
users are free to move between any social network provider that they choose.

In contrast, federated solutions, like Mastodon or Diaspora, ultimately place a
user's entire online presence in the hands of a few server operators. While
users are free to choose their server operator initially, once registered with a
given server, the user's data,
node.plaintext:
Blockchain technology provides a means for implementing a truly decentralized
social network where no single authority can control any one user's data and
users are free to move between any social network provider that they choose.

In contrast, federated solutions, like Mastodon or Diaspora, ultimately place a
user's entire online presence in the hands of a few server operators. While
users are free to choose their server operator initially, once registered with a
given server, the user's data, including content and social graph, is under the
control of that server's management. Users are free to leave if they don't like
a server's management or policies, but they can't take their data with them when
they go. In effect, their online life is not under their control.

By storing user's social graph and activity on the blockchain, the DSNP
guarantees that users are not beholden to anyone, and if they take issue with
their social provider, they can always move to another with the assurance that
all their friends, settings and content will come with them. They could even use
multiple providers at once for different purposes and feature sets.
node.html:
Blockchain technology provides a means for implementing a truly decentralized social network where no single authority can control any one user's data and users are free to move between any social network provider that they choose.

In contrast, federated solutions, like Mastodon or Diaspora, ultimately place a user's entire online presence in the hands of a few server operators. While users are free to choose their server operator initially, once registered with a given server, the user's data, including content and social graph, is under the control of that server's management. Users are free to leave if they don't like a server's management or policies, but they can't take their data with them when they go. In effect, their online life is not under their control.

By storing user's social graph and activity on the blockchain, the DSNP guarantees that users are not beholden to anyone, and if they take issue with their social provider, they can always move to another with the assurance that all their friends, settings and content will come with them. They could even use multiple providers at once for different purposes and feature sets.

node.title: Are you building a Facebook-killer?
node.excerpt:
No. We're building the low-level infrastructure that will make it easy for apps
to be socially-enabled without being beholden to any of the incumbent social
media giants.  We're not killing Facebook so much as giving people more options.
node.plaintext:
No. We're building the low-level infrastructure that will make it easy for apps
to be socially-enabled without being beholden to any of the incumbent social
media giants.  We're not killing Facebook so much as giving people more options.
node.html: No. We're building the low-level infrastructure that will make it easy for apps to be socially-enabled without being beholden to any of the incumbent social media giants.  We're not killing Facebook so much as giving people more options.

node.title: How will you build a base of users?
node.excerpt:
We plan to partner with existing communities and businesses to bring large
audiences to our network en masse.  Each of those networks will connect
seamlessly to each other.  All of those users will be able to talk to each
other, regardless of how they originally started using DSNP.
node.plaintext:
We plan to partner with existing communities and businesses to bring large
audiences to our network en masse.  Each of those networks will connect
seamlessly to each other.  All of those users will be able to talk to each
other, regardless of how they originally started using DSNP.
node.html: We plan to partner with existing communities and businesses to bring large audiences to our network en masse.  Each of those networks will connect seamlessly to each other.  All of those users will be able to talk to each other, regardless of how they originally started using DSNP.

node.title: Why do we need the DSNP?
node.excerpt:
Existing social media sites are all silos that trap users—leaving Facebook means
leaving your friends, and nobody wants to do that.  We want to make the social
connections between users independent of the particular websites they might use
to send messages and share photos.  This will free users to choose their social
media app for its features (like privacy!) and to change that choice at any time
without having to give up existing connections with their friends and family.
node.plaintext:
Existing social media sites are all silos that trap users—leaving Facebook means
leaving your friends, and nobody wants to do that.  We want to make the social
connections between users independent of the particular websites they might use
to send messages and share photos.  This will free users to choose their social
media app for its features (like privacy!) and to change that choice at any time
without having to give up existing connections with their friends and family.
node.html: Existing social media sites are all silos that trap users—leaving Facebook means leaving your friends, and nobody wants to do that.  We want to make the social connections between users independent of the particular websites they might use to send messages and share photos.  This will free users to choose their social media app for its features (like privacy!) and to change that choice at any time without having to give up existing connections with their friends and family.
